title: Benzodiazepine Conversion Calculator
description: Provides equivalents between different benzodiazepines for safe medication interchanging

parameters.name: converting_from
parameters.description: Current benzodiazepine medication being converted from

parameters.name: total_daily_dose
parameters.description: Total daily dosage of current benzodiazepine in milligrams

parameters.name: converting_to
parameters.description: Target benzodiazepine medication being converted to

result.name: equivalent_dose
result.description: Equivalent daily dose of target benzodiazepine

ranges.interpretation: Use lower end of dose range to minimize oversedation risk. Monitor for withdrawal symptoms and adjust as needed based on clinical response.

references: Ashton H. Benzodiazepines: how they work and how to withdraw. The Ashton Manual. 2002. Available at: https://www.benzo.org.uk/manual/
Lader M, Tylee A, Donoghue J. Withdrawing benzodiazepines in primary care. CNS Drugs. 2009;23(1):19-34.
Parr JM, Kavanagh DJ, Cahill L, et al. Effectiveness of current treatment approaches for benzodiazepine discontinuation: a meta-analysis. Addiction. 2009 Jan;104(1):13-24.
formula: Target dose (mg) = Current dose (mg) Ã— (Target potency factor / Current potency factor)
notes: Intended for use when interchanging benzodiazepines, NOT for calculating initial doses for benzodiazepine-naive patients
Does not account for age, organ function, or individual variability in metabolism
Use lower end of dose range to minimize oversedation risk
Abrupt discontinuation should be avoided due to potential withdrawal symptoms
Consider half-life differences when timing dose conversions
Monitor closely for signs of oversedation or withdrawal
Conversion factors are approximate and may require clinical adjustment
Short-acting benzodiazepines are generally more potent than long-acting ones
